summary_reasoning: The report demonstrates solid analytical depth with clear causal links and explicit, quantified assumptions, though it lacks formal sensitivity/scenario analysis. Strong causal explanations include “reflecting improved efficiency,” “margin pressure from investments in AI and logistics,” and AWS growth moderation as “customers optimize spending.” The inference quality is anchored by a DCF with stated drivers: “assumes a 10% revenue CAGR over five years,” “Operating margins expand… to 12% by 2029,” “WACC of 8.0%,” and “Terminal growth is 4%.” Quantification is used extensively (Q1 metrics, guidance ranges, segment growth rates, EPS bridge), and some benchmarking appears (“aligned with historical averages” for multiples; revenue CAGR linked “based on Q1 growth and guidance”). However, several assumptions are only generically justified (terminal growth, WACC inputs) and not stress-tested. Counterpoints and uncertainty are noted—“we see downside if AWS growth decelerates” and “valuation swings of ±20% possible”—but the report stops short of quantifying impacts on EPS or fair value across scenarios. Actionable guidance exists (“Investors should monitor AI capital expenditures”), yet decision-relevant implications would be stronger with sensitivities (e.g., AWS growth ±5 pts, margin ±100 bps) mapped to valuation. Overall, mechanisms and quantified assumptions are present, but the absence of explicit, quantified sensitivity/scenario analysis caps the depth.

missing_mechanisms: Capex to FCF impact not quantitatively linked
AWS deceleration to valuation pathway not shown
Advertising mix to margin uplift mechanism limited
lack_of_sensitivity: No margin sensitivity to AI capex
